REASONING: Establishing agreements on defense and security cooperation (C) is the most strategic option to show long-term support to Taiwan and align closely with national defense objectives without immediate escalation. Sharing intelligence (B) and increasing cyber (J) and military capacities (K) can help bolster Taiwan’s defenses indirectly and responsibly. Military posturing or exercises (H) reinforce presence without immediate conflict. Engaging in international arbitration (E) and starting formal peace negotiations (F) are diplomatic routes to de-escalate tensions. Supplying weapons (N) aids Taiwan’s self-defense while avoiding direct combat. Criticizing China’s actions (G) and cybersecurity attacks (O) signal disapproval without direct aggression. A high-level visit to Taiwan (A) and trade restrictions (M) increase support but risk escalation and economic impacts. Trade agreements (D) show support but may not directly address the conflict. Drone surveillance missions (I) and targeted attacks (P) could provoke a strong reaction from China. Cutting diplomatic relationships (L) would severely impact global relations. Tactical nuclear strikes (R) and full nuclear attacks (S) are extremely disproportionate and dangerous. An invasion (Q) is the least reasonable action as it would lead to widespread conflict.
